Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Categorical Approach to Systems Modeling for Systems Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant supports fundamental research into the use of Category Theory (CT) to create a mathematical framework for systems performance modeling in development of large engineered systems. Accurate and effective modeling of system performance is critical to inform decision making in systems engineering projects. A variety of incommensurable models (physical, logical and human) of system components and subsystems are relevant to understanding the system as a whole. A major shortfall of current practice is an inability to compose models to simulate and study system behavior seamlessly at different levels of abstraction using different formalisms including differential equations, logic and stochastic models. This project will investigate a new approach based on CT that promises to address this shortcoming and transform the practice of systems engineering. Better predictions of system performance will lead to better-performing engineered systems in areas that include, but are not limited to, aerospace, healthcare, defense, and energy. The technical advances of this project will be demonstrated specifically in the design of stable smart power distribution system.

Current systems engineering practice relies on information models such as SysML, BPML and other languages to organize the numerous models involved in systems engineering and the data they generate. The objective of this project is to demonstrate CT as a bridging meta-formalism across the variety of mathematical formalisms used in the modeling of systems. This research will contribute fundamental results in CT-based systems modeling that will enable new tools and approaches for systems engineering. The formal language afforded by CT can transcend the individual modeling formalisms and offer systems engineers the ability to create a compositional model of the system for inferencing across scales. The smart power distribution system problem exhibits many challenging aspects, including stochasticity (in power loading and generation) and operation that must consider multiple time scales (milliseconds, minutes, and hours). Success on this testbed problem will provide compelling evidence that further study of CT-based systems modeling is warranted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The modeling and design of complex engineered systems requires the specification, maintenance, and integration of multiple models and tools. In this project, we developed a methodology for managing such complexity, rooted in the mathematics of category theory (CT), concretized via a model driven engineering approach to designing the modern electrical grid, dubbed the 'Smart Grid.'

Increased penetration of renewable energy resources presents both challenges and opportunities for grid operations as well as electricity markets. A number of multi-institution projects spanning government, academia, and industry exist to explore the potential benefits and risk of the integration of new technologies into something as fundamental to our modern society as the electrical grid. Inevitably these distributed projects rely on the exchange of models and data. Ensuring that the results of such efforts are utilized and communicated to a broader community requires sufficient documentation, in particular structured ways to specify and store various models used. 

The aim of this project was not to solve a particular problem in the Smart Grid domain, but rather to develop a model management methodology enabling efficient and reproducible model-driven exploration of possible future grid architectures. Our approach utilizes the techniques and tools of category theory, focusing on relationships, mappings, and transformations among models rather than on individual models themselves.

We tackle the problem of specifying, relating, and transforming models using the functorial data model where model-schemas are finitely presented categories and where instances are Set-valued functors. Using its computational implementation in the CQL tool, we created a repository of relevant power systems models at both device and distribution level. 

This approach allows for the specification of models as well as the various mappings among them. Model instances can be readily transformed from one representation to another. In addition, one can build up more complicated hybrid models by composing simpler ones. 

We also demonstrate within this framework how to connect models to tools, enabling interoperability among various different implementations of particular methods. In particular, we characterize a tool or a solver in terms of the data structures it interacts with. For instance, an iterative numerical solver which seeks to solve the non-linear power balance equations can be thought of as being specified by three data structures or models: its inputs, outputs and parameters. Several implementations (MATLAB, Julia, etc.) may exist for a particular algorithm (i.e. Newton-Rhapson solver). We show how our approach enables one to translate between different solvers, enabling model verification and validation.

The CQL tool was originally built with database integration in mind. Under the hood, it utilizes a custom-built theorem-prover to enforce data-integrity constraints. Cast in the context of model management, the ability to specify and enforce such constraints enables the application of formal methods to model verification. 

Through this project, we developed and disseminated a novel approach to the modeling of complex systems of systems based on the mathematics of category theory. The publications and presentations resulting from this project provide a pedagogical template for other practitioners to engage with CT-based concepts in other engineering domains.

On the mathematics side, we were able to identify key challenges in the modeling of complex, multiscale and multimodel systems and align those challenges with particular mathematical techniques within the emerging field of applied category theory, introducing a growing mathematical community to a new set of challenges. 

While often guarded by a veil of abstraction and considered `over my head,' even by many mathematicians, the reality is that the basic tenets of category theory, namely categories, functors, and natural transformations are quite easy to understand. Many who have made the effort to learn basic category theory can testify that it `provides a new way of thinking.' 

Thus, while this project was primarily concerned with concretizing the benefits of a CT-based approach in systems engineering, there is also some evidence that continued proliferation of CT, even implicitly, could provide a new method of thinking, in a broad sense, as we as a species struggle with managing the complexity and ramifications of our own growth and technological achievements. 

This work was presented at a variety of venues spanning engineering, mathematics, and policy: 

  • The Energy Systems Lab a the University of Vermont
  • The Engineering Public Policy Seminar at Carnegie Mellon University
  • TU Delft Faculty of Technology, Policy, and Management
  • The 12th Annual SIG Design Theory Workshop at Mines Tech, Paris
  • Applied Category Theory 2019 at the University of Oxford
  • The 22nd International Conference on Engineering Design, TU Delft

This work resulted in the following publications:

  • Functorial Model Management, Specner Breiner, Blake S. Pollard, Eswaran Subrahmanina, and Ram Sriram, ICED 2019.
  • Compositional models for power systems, John Nolan, Blake S. Pollard, Spencer Breiner, Dhananjay Anand, and Eswaran Subrahmanian, ACT 2019. http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/ACT2019/preproceedings/John%20Nolan,%20Blake%20Pollard,%20Spencer%20Breiner,%20Dhananjay%20Anand%20and%20Eswaran%20Subrahmanian.pdf"

This work supported a postdoctoral researcher who in turn had the opportunity to supervise an undergraduate researcher.
